results.title: Speech skills: using your voice effectively
results.brief_description: In a television setting, pictures projected onto a screen change to live-action examples of situations where the effective use of your voice is important. Problems that are the result of the speaker’s volume, pitch, voice quality and articulation are examined, with suggestions for overcoming them.

results.title: Speech and protest
results.brief_description: Queries the limits to freedom of speech and assembly in America in 1967. After introducing the First Amendment, three enacted sequences are presented: in the first, students in a classroom argue about the government’s foreign policies; in the second, the teacher forcefully leads the discussion, raising the question of academic freedom and the wishes of parents; the third sequence deals with an anti-war demonstration in which a threatening crowd forms, which questions the duty of the police. The film presents conflicting opinions and controversial scenes. It’s purpose: to let you find out what you think. Footage includes demonstrations for civil rights, women’s rights, African-American protest, KKK meetings.

results.title: Speech and language disorders
results.creator_credit: Queensland. Dept. of Education. Media Services
results.brief_description: A comprehensive introduction to the work of speech therapists. Looks at speech and language disorders in children, such as, poor communication and stuttering; and the problems adults face after strokes and throat cancers. Suitable for teacher/tertiary level.

results.title: Spectrum: psychobiology - split brain (D)
results.creator_credit: David Prowitt, National Educational Television, International Science Magazine, Philip Burton and Jack Willis
results.brief_description: This informative piece is based around a doctor who experiments on animals to find out what significance each side of the brain has, thus a monkey is operated on to “split his brain”. Tests are then run to monitor the monkey’s process. Split brain people are then looked into to find out what the left and right side of the brain does. NB: CONTAINS DISTURBING IMAGES OF ANIMAL EXPERIMENTATION.

results.title: Spectacular canyons
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Journal Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Natural Phenomena Series”.
Uses diagrams and spectacular photography to introduce the geomorphological agents involved in the creation of canyons. Covers rivers, valleys and glacial valleys showing the processes of weathering and erosion. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Spectacular Britain
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: David Attenborough takes the viewer the length of Britain in one year. Some of its most beautiful countryside is shown as well as some fascinating wildlife. The gardens of Buckingham Palace are filmed for the first time.

results.title: Specialist panel work
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Panel & paint”.
Provides instructions in advanced panel beating. Lessons include, lead wiping, metal finishing, shrinking, welding and rust removal.

results.title: Special treatment: locking up aboriginal children
results.creator_credit: Margaret Anne Smith and Smith Street Films
results.brief_description: Young Aboriginal people are no longer removed from their families by the authorities “for their own good”, but young Aborigines are still subject to forcible removal from their families and friends through imprisonment in juvenile prisons for petty crimes. This program focuses on the experiences of young Aborigines in New South Wales who tell of a high degree of police harassment, simply because they are black. Their views are in stark contrast to those held by the white law enforcers interviewed, who see themselves to be free of racism despite the fact that there is a massive over-representation of Aborigines in Australian prisons.
